name: Choe Yun-ui
summary: Choe Yun-ui was a Goryeo Dynasty official who is credited with inventing the world's first metal movable type printing around 1234-1250, predating Gutenberg by about 200 years. The Jikji, the oldest surviving book printed with metal movable type, dates from this tradition. His innovation revolutionized printing technology in Korea.

name: Jang Gi-ryang
summary: Jang Gi-ryang was a Korean entomologist who systematically classified Korean insect species during the colonial period. He documented hundreds of native Korean insect species and developed integrated pest management techniques for Korean rice paddies. His taxonomic work laid the foundation for Korean entomological science.
timeline: Developed pest management for rice cultivation

name: Lee Dong-nyeong
summary: Lee Dong-nyeong was a Korean organic chemist who developed novel pharmaceutical compounds at the Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT). His work on synthesizing bioactive natural product analogs contributed to Korean pharmaceutical independence and helped establish Korea's drug development capabilities.

name: Park Se-jik
summary: Park Se-jik was a Korean nuclear physicist who played a crucial role in training Korea's first generation of nuclear engineers. He helped establish nuclear physics programs at Seoul National University and contributed to the design of Korea's research reactors. His educational efforts were vital for Korea's nuclear energy development.

name: Kim Sam-sun
summary: Kim Sam-sun was a Korean botanist who conducted extensive surveys of Korean mountain flora and documented rare and endemic plant species. She was one of the first Korean women to work in botanical science and contributed to the preservation records of Korea's unique alpine plant communities.
timeline: Began plant surveys in Korean mountains

name: Ahn Cheol-su
summary: Ahn Cheol-su is a Korean computer scientist who founded AhnLab in 1995, South Korea's leading cybersecurity company. He created V3, one of the world's first commercial antivirus programs, in 1988. Originally a physician, he transitioned to computer science and became a pioneer of the Korean IT security industry. He later entered politics.
timeline: Earned MD from Seoul National University
Became dean of KAIST Graduate School
Earned PhD from University of Pennsylvania

name: Lee Chan-hee
summary: Lee Chan-hee was a Korean marine biologist who pioneered seaweed aquaculture research in South Korea. His work on laver (gim) and kelp cultivation techniques helped establish Korea as one of the world's leading seaweed producers. He developed improved cultivation methods that increased yields and quality of edible seaweed.

name: Uichiro Nakaya
summary: Uichiro Nakaya was a Japanese physicist who was the first person to create artificial snow crystals in a laboratory in 1936. He systematically classified natural snow crystals and showed that crystal shapes depend on temperature and humidity conditions. His Nakaya diagram remains the standard classification system for snow crystal morphology.
timeline: Began studying snow crystals at Hokkaido University

name: Kato Hiroyuki
summary: Although primarily a political thinker, Kato Hiroyuki was an important figure in introducing Western science and technology to Meiji Japan. As president of Tokyo Imperial University, he established Japan's modern scientific education system and advocated for Social Darwinism and the adoption of Western scientific methods throughout Japanese universities.
timeline: Became first president of University of Tokyo
Published works on evolution and social science

name: Ogata Koan
summary: Ogata Koan was a Japanese physician and scholar who founded the Tekijuku school in Osaka, which trained many of Japan's future leaders in Western medicine and science. He translated Dutch medical texts and promoted smallpox vaccination in Japan. His students included Fukuzawa Yukichi and other key figures of Japan's modernization.
timeline: Appointed head of the Shogunate's medical academy

name: Hanabusa Itcho
summary: Hanabusa Itcho, while primarily known as a painter, also documented various technological innovations of the Edo period including mechanical devices, agricultural tools, and artisan techniques. His detailed illustrations of technology and daily life serve as important records of Edo-period Japanese technology and craftsmanship.

name: Takebe Katahiro
summary: Takebe Katahiro was a Japanese mathematician and student of Seki Takakazu who made remarkable advances in wasan mathematics. He calculated pi to 41 decimal places using the Archimedean method with 1,024-sided polygons and developed Richardson extrapolation independently of Western mathematicians. He also contributed to the development of Japanese calculus.

name: Aida Yasuaki
summary: Aida Yasuaki was a Japanese mathematician of the Edo period who contributed to wasan mathematics, particularly in the areas of algebraic equations and series expansions. He established his own mathematical school and published numerous works on advanced mathematical problems. His sangaku (mathematical tablet) contributions are notable.

name: Hashimoto Sanai
summary: Hashimoto Sanai was a Japanese physician and scholar of Western studies (rangaku) who advocated for adopting Western science and medicine in late Edo period Japan. He studied Western medicine and chemistry and proposed radical modernization reforms. He was executed during the Ansei Purge at age 25 for his reformist activities.

name: Satake Shozan
summary: Satake Shozan was a Japanese feudal lord (daimyo) of the Akita domain who was unusual among the samurai class for his deep interest in Western science, particularly mineralogy and Western-style painting. He promoted rangaku (Dutch learning) in his domain and encouraged the study of natural sciences and mining technology.
timeline: Met Dutch studies scholar Hiraga Gennai

name: Hiraga Gennai
summary: Hiraga Gennai was an Edo-period Japanese polymath who studied Western science and created an erekiteru (static electricity generator), experimented with asbestos, and promoted botanical studies and mining technology. He organized Japan's first exhibition of natural products and was an early advocate for applying Western science to Japanese industry.
timeline: Born in Shido, Sanuki Province, Japan
Organized first Japanese natural products exhibition

name: Shiba Kokan
summary: Shiba Kokan was a Japanese painter and scientist who was one of the first Japanese to study and apply Western scientific methods including Copernican astronomy, perspective drawing, and copperplate engraving. He published works on astronomy showing the heliocentric model and created oil paintings using Western techniques, bridging Japanese and European scientific traditions.
timeline: Published astronomical works based on Copernican model
Produced oil paintings using Western techniques

name: Asada Goryu
summary: Asada Goryu was a Japanese astronomer of the Edo period who independently developed heliocentric ideas and improved astronomical calculations. He established an astronomical school in Osaka and trained students who went on to reform Japan's calendar system. He was the first Japanese astronomer to study celestial mechanics systematically.
timeline: Born in Kitsuki, Bungo Province, Japan
Trained students who reformed calendar system

name: Hazama Shigetomi
summary: Hazama Shigetomi was a Japanese merchant and astronomer from Osaka who was a student of Asada Goryu. He built precise astronomical instruments and conducted detailed observations of eclipses and planetary movements. His observations were used to reform the Japanese calendar (Kansei calendar) and he helped modernize Japanese astronomy.

name: Itakura Katsukiyo
summary: Itakura Katsukiyo was a Japanese daimyo who implemented innovative agricultural irrigation systems in his domain. He developed water management infrastructure that increased rice yields and established flood control measures. His agricultural engineering projects became models for other domains across Japan.

name: Hua Tuo
summary: Hua Tuo was an ancient Chinese physician who is considered the first surgeon to use general anesthesia during surgery, using a formulation called mafeisan (hemp boiling powder). He performed complex surgeries including abdominal operations and is said to have offered to operate on Cao Cao's brain. He also developed wuqinxi, exercises mimicking five animals.
timeline: Born in Qiao County, Han Dynasty China

name: Wan Hu
summary: Wan Hu is a legendary Chinese official from the Ming Dynasty who is said to have attempted manned rocket flight by strapping 47 rockets to a chair. Though the historical accuracy is debated, his story represents China's early ambitions in rocketry. A crater on the far side of the Moon is named after him, honoring this tradition of Chinese rocket experimentation.
timeline: Lunar crater named Wan-Hoo in his honor

name: Du Shi
summary: Du Shi was a Han Dynasty Chinese government official and engineer who in 31 AD invented the first water-powered bellows for iron smelting, using a water wheel to drive piston bellows. This innovation greatly improved iron production efficiency and quality, helping drive Chinese metallurgical advancement over a millennium before similar technology appeared in Europe.
timeline: Invented water-powered bellows for blast furnaces

name: Cai Wenji
summary: Cai Wenji, while primarily known as a poet and musician, was one of the most learned women in Chinese history. She could recite from memory thousands of books and had mastery of mathematics and astronomy. She represents the tradition of female scholarship in ancient China, though her scientific contributions were not formally recorded.
timeline: Born in Chen Liu, Han Dynasty China
Captured by Xiongnu during civil war

name: Ma Jun
summary: Ma Jun was a Three Kingdoms era Chinese mechanical engineer who improved the south-pointing chariot (a non-magnetic compass vehicle using differential gears), built a chain pump for irrigation, and created mechanical puppet theater. He is considered one of the greatest mechanical engineers in Chinese history, known for his innovative problem-solving abilities.

name: Lu Ban
summary: Lu Ban was an ancient Chinese carpenter, engineer, and inventor who is revered as the patron saint of Chinese builders. He is credited with inventing the saw, the carpenter's plane, the drill, the shovel, and the grappling hook. He also created a wooden bird that could fly for three days. He was considered the greatest artisan in Chinese history.
timeline: Created siege ladder and grappling hook

name: Zheng He
summary: Zheng He was a Chinese admiral and explorer who commanded enormous treasure fleets on seven epic voyages (1405-1433) across the Indian Ocean, reaching Southeast Asia, India, Arabia, and East Africa. His ships were the largest wooden vessels ever built. His voyages demonstrated Chinese maritime technological supremacy and advanced navigation, cartography, and shipbuilding.
timeline: First voyage with fleet of 317 ships
Died during return from seventh voyage

name: Zhu Zaiyu
summary: Zhu Zaiyu was a Ming Dynasty prince and polymath who was the first person to mathematically calculate equal temperament tuning for music in 1584, predating Simon Stevin's work. He used precise mathematical calculations involving the twelfth root of two. This discovery was fundamental to modern Western music and the standardization of musical tuning worldwide.
timeline: Born in Henan, Ming Dynasty China

name: Joseph Achille Le Bel
summary: Joseph Le Bel was a French chemist who independently proposed, simultaneously with Jacobus Henricus van 't Hoff, the tetrahedral arrangement of carbon bonds in 1874. This concept of stereochemistry explained optical isomerism and was fundamental to understanding three-dimensional molecular structure in organic chemistry.

name: Sahachiro Hata
summary: Sahachiro Hata was a Japanese bacteriologist who, working with Paul Ehrlich in Germany, discovered Salvarsan (arsphenamine), the first effective treatment for syphilis, in 1909. He tested hundreds of organoarsenic compounds before finding compound 606, which became the most prescribed drug in the world. This was the birth of chemotherapy.
timeline: Graduated from Tokyo Imperial University Medical School
Went to study under Paul Ehrlich in Frankfurt

name: Ueda Akinari
summary: Ueda Akinari was a Japanese writer and physician who, beyond his famous literary works, practiced herbal medicine and studied pharmacology. He was trained as a physician and herbalist, applying traditional Chinese and Japanese medical knowledge. His medical practice informed his literary depictions of human nature and suffering.

name: Sakuma Shozan
summary: Sakuma Shozan was a late Edo period Japanese scholar and technologist who experimented with Western science and military technology. He cast cannons using Western techniques, built a telegraph device, and experimented with glass-making. He advocated 'Eastern ethics, Western science' and trained many reform leaders. He was assassinated by anti-Western extremists.
timeline: Assassinated in Kyoto by anti-Western samurai

name: Kawamoto Komin
summary: Kawamoto Komin was a Japanese physician and scholar of Western sciences (rangaku) who wrote the Kikai Kanran Kogi (Outline of Physical Science), one of the first Japanese texts on Western physics and chemistry. He translated and adapted Western scientific works and experimented with photography, telegraphy, and chemistry.
timeline: Studied Western science through Dutch texts
Published Kikai Kanran Kogi (Western physics text)

name: Udagawa Yoan
summary: Udagawa Yoan was a Japanese scholar of Western studies who introduced modern chemistry and botany to Japan. His Seimi Kaiso (Introduction to Chemistry, 1837) was the first Japanese chemistry textbook. He coined many Japanese scientific terms still in use today, including the Japanese words for oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, and carbon.
timeline: Published Seimi Kaiso (first Japanese chemistry textbook)
Coined Japanese terms for chemical elements

name: Udagawa Genshin
summary: Udagawa Genshin was a Japanese physician and scholar of Dutch studies who translated and adapted Western anatomy and medical texts. His 1805 work Ihan Teiko (Western Medical Pharmacopoeia) introduced systematic Western pharmacology to Japan. He was the adoptive father of Udagawa Yoan and a pioneer of Western medicine in Japan.
timeline: Advanced Western medical education in Japan

name: Yamawaki Toyo
summary: Yamawaki Toyo was a Japanese physician who performed the first officially sanctioned human dissection in Japan in 1754, challenging the traditional Chinese anatomical descriptions used in Japanese medicine. His observations, published in Zoshi (Record of Organs), showed that actual human anatomy differed from classical Chinese texts, advancing empirical medicine in Japan.
timeline: Performed first sanctioned human dissection in Japan

name: Sugita Genpaku
summary: Sugita Genpaku was a Japanese physician who co-translated Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy) in 1774, the first translation of a Western medical text into Japanese. This landmark translation, based on a Dutch anatomy book, transformed Japanese understanding of human anatomy and marked the beginning of serious Western medical study in Japan.
timeline: Observed dissection matching Dutch anatomy text
Published Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy)
Advanced Western medical studies in Japan

name: Takano Choei
summary: Takano Choei was a Japanese physician and rangaku scholar who studied Western medicine and sciences. He wrote about Western vaccination methods and warned about the dangers of isolationism in his essay Yume Monogatari (Tale of a Dream). He was imprisoned for his progressive views but escaped and continued clandestine scientific work until his death.
timeline: Studied under Philipp Franz von Siebold

name: Philipp Franz von Siebold
summary: Philipp Franz von Siebold was a German physician and naturalist who introduced Western medicine to Japan and brought knowledge of Japanese natural history to Europe. During his time in Nagasaki (1823-1829), he trained Japanese physicians and collected specimens. His Flora Japonica and Fauna Japonica were landmark works on Japanese natural history.
timeline: Trained Japanese physicians in Western medicine
Banished from Japan for possessing maps

name: Sanghyuk Lee
summary: Sanghyuk Lee is a Korean bioinformatician who has made significant contributions to genomics and bioinformatics research in South Korea. His work on genome analysis and computational biology has helped establish Korea's capabilities in precision medicine and genomic research, contributing to projects like the Korean reference genome.
timeline: Contributed to Korean reference genome project

name: Kim Woo-choong
summary: Kim Woo-choong was a Korean engineer and industrialist who founded Daewoo Group, which became one of Korea's largest conglomerates. Starting with a small textile company in 1967, he built Daewoo into a global enterprise spanning automobiles, shipbuilding, electronics, and construction. His engineering-driven approach epitomized Korean industrial development.
timeline: Expanded into heavy industry and engineering
Daewoo collapsed in Asian financial crisis

name: Kwon Oh-hyun
summary: Kwon Oh-hyun is a Korean electrical engineer who led Samsung Electronics' semiconductor division to global dominance. As CEO and Vice Chairman, he oversaw the development of advanced memory chips and processors that made Samsung the world's largest semiconductor manufacturer. His technical leadership was critical to Samsung's technological ascendancy.
timeline: Earned PhD in electrical engineering from Stanford

name: Lee Byung-chul
summary: Lee Byung-chul was a Korean industrialist who founded Samsung Group in 1938, growing it from a small trading company into South Korea's largest conglomerate. Under his leadership, Samsung expanded into electronics, engineering, and semiconductors. His vision of technology-driven industrial development shaped modern South Korea's economic miracle.
timeline: Born in Uiryeong, South Gyeongsang Province

name: Chung Ju-yung
summary: Chung Ju-yung was a Korean industrialist who founded Hyundai Group and transformed it into a global engineering and industrial conglomerate. He built Korea's first supertanker, established Hyundai Motor Company, and constructed major infrastructure projects worldwide. His engineering achievements helped drive South Korea's rapid industrialization.

name: Lim Chee-Onn
summary: Lim Chee-Onn is a Singaporean engineer who played a key role in developing Singapore's infrastructure and technology sector. His engineering and policy work contributed to Singapore's transformation from a developing nation into a global technology hub. He served in multiple government and corporate leadership positions.
timeline: Studied engineering at University of Adelaide

name: Bai Chunli
summary: Bai Chunli is a Chinese chemist and nanoscientist who served as president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences from 2011 to 2020. He pioneered scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) research in China and made significant contributions to nanoscale surface science. His work advanced China's capabilities in nanotechnology and materials science.
timeline: Earned PhD from Chinese Academy of Sciences
Elected to Chinese Academy of Sciences
Became president of Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Pan Jianwei
summary: Pan Jianwei is a Chinese physicist who is the leading figure in China's quantum technology program. He led the development of the Micius quantum satellite, the world's first quantum communication satellite launched in 2016. He has demonstrated quantum teleportation over record distances and established intercontinental quantum key distribution.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Vienna under Anton Zeilinger
Achieved quantum computational advantage with Jiuzhang

name: Lu Yongxiang
summary: Lu Yongxiang is a Chinese mechanical engineer who served as president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences from 1997 to 2011. He made significant contributions to fluid power transmission and control, developing new hydraulic systems for Chinese industrial machinery. Under his leadership, CAS expanded China's basic research capabilities significantly.
timeline: Earned PhD from RWTH Aachen in Germany
Advanced fluid power research at Zhejiang University
Became president of Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Wang Daheng
summary: Wang Daheng was a Chinese optical physicist known as the 'Father of Chinese Optics.' He founded China's optical engineering discipline and developed optical instruments for China's military and space programs. He was one of the key figures behind China's high-technology development plan (863 Program) and helped establish China's laser and fiber optics research.
timeline: Earned PhD from Imperial College London

name: Qian Weichang
summary: Qian Weichang was a Chinese physicist and applied mathematician who made significant contributions to elasticity theory and variational methods. He studied under Theodore von Kármán at Caltech and developed important theories of thin shells and plates used in aerospace engineering. He helped modernize Chinese scientific education.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Toronto
Studied under von Kármán at Caltech
Advanced shell theory and applied mathematics

name: Fang Lizhi
summary: Fang Lizhi was a Chinese astrophysicist who made contributions to cosmology and the physics of the early universe. He became famous as China's most prominent pro-democracy advocate in the 1980s, earning the nickname 'China's Andrei Sakharov.' After the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, he sought refuge in the US embassy and later taught at the University of Arizona.
timeline: Advocated for academic freedom and democracy
Sought refuge in US embassy after Tiananmen

name: Zhong Nanshan
summary: Zhong Nanshan is a Chinese pulmonologist who gained national fame for his role in identifying and combating the SARS epidemic in 2003. He was among the first to alert the public to the severity of SARS and developed treatment protocols that reduced mortality. In 2020, he again played a leading role in China's COVID-19 response.
timeline: Became director of Guangzhou Institute of Respiratory Disease
Led advisory role in China's COVID-19 response

name: Xie Yi
summary: Note: This is a different researcher from Yi Xie. Xie Yi has contributed to Chinese chemistry research in the field of coordination chemistry and crystal engineering. Her work on metal-organic frameworks has advanced understanding of porous materials for gas storage and separation.

name: Tan Jiazhen
summary: Tan Jiazhen (C.C. Tan) was a Chinese geneticist known as the 'father of Chinese genetics.' He studied under T.H. Morgan at Caltech and discovered the mosaic dominance phenomenon in ladybird beetles. He established genetics research and education in China and served as president of Fudan University for over 20 years.
timeline: Earned PhD from Caltech under T.H. Morgan

name: Zhu Xi-Ran
summary: Zhu Xi-Ran is a Chinese agricultural scientist who developed high-yield cotton varieties that significantly increased China's cotton production. Her hybrid cotton breeding program combined disease resistance with improved fiber quality, helping China become the world's largest cotton producer.
timeline: Cotton varieties widely adopted across China

name: Pingala
summary: Pingala was an ancient Indian mathematician who described binary numbers, Pascal's triangle (Meru Prastara), and the Fibonacci sequence in his treatise on Sanskrit prosody (Chandahshastra) around 200 BC. His work anticipated these mathematical concepts by centuries before their Western 'discovery.' He used binary-like notation to classify Sanskrit meters.

name: Nagarjuna
summary: Nagarjuna was an ancient Indian philosopher and alchemist-metallurgist who wrote the Rasaratnakara, documenting chemical processes including the extraction and purification of metals, preparation of mercury compounds, and creating alloys. While famous for his Buddhist philosophy (Madhyamaka), his alchemical work advanced Indian metallurgical and chemical knowledge significantly.

name: Varahamihira
summary: Varahamihira was an ancient Indian astronomer and mathematician who authored the Pancha Siddhantika, summarizing five earlier astronomical texts, and the Brihat Samhita, an encyclopedia of natural sciences. He accurately described the concept of gravity, recognized the existence of comets, and made contributions to combinatorics and trigonometry.

name: Hemachandra
summary: Hemachandra was a medieval Indian Jain scholar who independently described what is now known as the Fibonacci sequence in 1150, before Leonardo of Pisa. He applied the sequence to problems in Sanskrit prosody. He also made contributions to mathematics, grammar, philosophy, and logic, and was one of the most prolific scholars of medieval India.
timeline: Published works on grammar and mathematics

name: Jagannatha Samrat
summary: Jagannatha Samrat was an Indian astronomer who worked at the court of Maharaja Jai Singh II and translated Euclid's Elements and Ptolemy's Almagest from Arabic into Sanskrit. His translations helped preserve and transmit mathematical knowledge in India. He also contributed to astronomical observations at the Jantar Mantar observatories.
timeline: Joined court of Jai Singh II

name: Sake Dean Mahomed
summary: Sake Dean Mahomed was an Indian surgeon and medical entrepreneur who introduced shampooing (therapeutic massage and steam baths) to Britain. He opened the first Indian restaurant in London (1810) and established Mahomed's Baths in Brighton, becoming 'Shampooing Surgeon' to both King George IV and King William IV. He was a pioneer of Indian therapeutic practices in the West.
timeline: Served in the British East India Company army
Opened first Indian restaurant in London
Appointed shampooing surgeon to King George IV

name: Anandi Gopal Joshi
summary: Anandi Gopal Joshi was one of the first Indian women to earn a medical degree, graduating from Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania in 1886. She traveled to America at age 18 to study medicine, overcoming immense societal opposition. Tragically, she died of tuberculosis at age 21, shortly after returning to India, but she inspired generations of Indian women doctors.
timeline: Traveled to the United States for medical education
Graduated from Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania
Died of tuberculosis in Pune at age 21

name: Radhanath Sikdar
summary: Radhanath Sikdar was an Indian mathematician who computed the height of Mount Everest, determining it to be the world's highest peak. Working as a chief computer (calculator) for the Great Trigonometric Survey of India under Andrew Waugh, he processed the survey data and first identified 'Peak XV' as the tallest mountain in 1852.
timeline: Joined Great Trigonometric Survey as computer
Calculated height of Peak XV (Mt. Everest)
Identified Mt. Everest as world's highest peak

name: Jamsetji Tata
summary: Jamsetji Tata was an Indian industrialist who founded the Tata Group, India's largest conglomerate. He established India's first modern steel plant (Tata Steel), the Indian Institute of Science, and the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel. His vision for India's industrialization through science and education laid the foundations for modern Indian industry and research.
timeline: Planned Tata Steel works at Jamshedpur
Built Taj Mahal Palace Hotel, Mumbai

name: Homi Sethna
summary: Homi Sethna was an Indian chemical engineer who served as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission of India. He led the development of plutonium reprocessing technology and played a key role in India's first nuclear test (Smiling Buddha) in 1974. His chemical engineering expertise was crucial for India's nuclear fuel cycle.
timeline: Became member of Atomic Energy Commission
Key role in Smiling Buddha nuclear test

name: Obaid Siddiqi
summary: Obaid Siddiqi was an Indian molecular biologist who founded the molecular biology program at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research (TIFR). He pioneered the use of Drosophila genetics to study the nervous system and discovered the first olfactory mutants in fruit flies. He founded the National Centre for Biological Sciences (NCBS) in Bangalore.
timeline: Born in Basti, Uttar Pradesh, India
Earned PhD from University of Glasgow
Founded NCBS (National Centre for Biological Sciences)

name: Ganapathi Thanikaimoni
summary: Ganapathi Thanikaimoni was an Indian palynologist who made significant contributions to the study of pollen morphology in tropical plants. His work at the Institut Français de Pondichéry documented the pollen of thousands of tropical plant species. He established systematic palynological research in India and trained many researchers.
timeline: Documented thousands of tropical pollen types

name: Al-Sufi
summary: Abd al-Rahman al-Sufi was a Persian astronomer who wrote the Book of Fixed Stars in 964, one of the most important medieval astronomical texts. He made the first recorded observation of the Andromeda Galaxy (calling it a 'nebulous smear') and the Large Magellanic Cloud. He corrected and updated Ptolemy's star catalog with improved magnitudes and positions.
timeline: First recorded observation of Andromeda Galaxy

name: Ibn Sahl
summary: Ibn Sahl was a Persian physicist and mathematician who discovered the law of refraction (Snell's law) in 984, over 600 years before Willebrord Snellius. His manuscript On Burning Mirrors and Lenses contains the first known accurate description of the law of refraction of light, demonstrated through the design of lenses with no geometric aberrations.
timeline: Advanced lens design using refraction law

name: Al-Battani
summary: Al-Battani was an Arab astronomer and mathematician who made remarkably precise astronomical observations over 40 years in Raqqa, Syria. He corrected Ptolemy's values for the length of the year, precession of the equinoxes, and the obliquity of the ecliptic. He introduced the use of trigonometric functions in astronomy, replacing Greek chord tables.

name: Al-Zarqali
summary: Al-Zarqali (Arzachel) was an Andalusian astronomer and instrument maker who developed an improved astrolabe (the Saphaea) that could be used at any latitude. He compiled the Toledan Tables, the most accurate astronomical tables of the medieval world. He also discovered the motion of the solar apogee and calculated the year's length with great precision.

name: Fatima al-Fihri
summary: Fatima al-Fihri was a Tunisian-born woman who founded the University of al-Qarawiyyin in Fez, Morocco in 859 AD, recognized by UNESCO and the Guinness World Records as the oldest continuously operating educational institution in the world. She used her inheritance to build the mosque-university, which became a center of learning in mathematics, sciences, and Islamic studies.

name: Mariam al-Astrulabi
summary: Mariam al-Astrulabi was a 10th-century Syrian woman astronomer and astrolabe maker, one of the few known female scientists of the medieval Islamic world. She apprenticed under her father, a noted astrolabe craftsman, and became skilled in designing and constructing astrolabes used for astronomical calculation and navigation. The main-belt asteroid 7060 is named after her.
timeline: Employed at court of Sayf al-Dawla

name: Jabir ibn Aflah
summary: Jabir ibn Aflah (Geber) was an Andalusian astronomer and mathematician who developed spherical trigonometry and corrected errors in Ptolemy's Almagest. His Islah al-Majisti (Correction of the Almagest) introduced simplified methods for astronomical calculation. His trigonometric work was later used by European astronomers including Regiomontanus.

name: Banū Shākir
summary: The Banū Shākir were three brothers (Muhammad, Ahmad, and Hasan) who were 9th-century Arab mathematicians and engineers at the Baghdad House of Wisdom. They wrote the Book of the Measurement of Plane and Spherical Figures, advancing geometry. Their engineering works included mechanical devices, canals, and they sponsored the translation of Greek scientific texts.
timeline: Published Book of the Measurement of Figures

name: Kushyar Gilani
summary: Kushyar Gilani was a Persian mathematician and astronomer who wrote influential texts on arithmetic and astronomy. His Principles of Hindu Reckoning helped transmit the Hindu-Arabic numeral system throughout the Islamic world and into Europe. He also compiled astronomical tables (zij) and advanced trigonometric calculations.

name: Musa al-Khwarizmi
summary: Already covered as Al-Khwarizmi — this entry is a duplicate check.

name: Abu Kamil
summary: Abu Kamil Shuja ibn Aslam was an Egyptian mathematician who advanced algebra beyond al-Khwarizmi's work, developing algebraic solutions to more complex problems including systems of equations and irrational numbers. His Kitab fi al-jabr wa al-muqabala influenced Leonardo of Pisa (Fibonacci) and was foundational for European algebra.
timeline: Developed solutions for systems of equations
Worked with irrational numbers in algebra

name: Ibn Yunus
summary: Ibn Yunus was an Egyptian astronomer who compiled the Hakimi zij, one of the most detailed astronomical tables of the medieval world. He made remarkably precise observations of solar and lunar eclipses over many years and developed new trigonometric methods. His astronomical tables were used by navigators and astronomers for centuries.

name: Kamāl al-Dīn al-Fārisī
summary: Kamal al-Din al-Farisi was a Persian physicist who provided the first correct explanation of the rainbow through his experiments with a glass sphere filled with water. His work Tanqih al-Manazir (Revision of Optics) advanced Ibn al-Haytham's optics and explained both primary and secondary rainbows through refraction and reflection of light inside water droplets.

name: Ibn al-Banna al-Marrakushi
summary: Ibn al-Banna was a Moroccan mathematician and astronomer who wrote Talkhis Amal al-Hisab, a concise treatise on arithmetic that became the standard mathematics textbook in the Maghreb for centuries. He introduced new methods for algebraic computation and combinatorics. He also contributed to astronomy and wrote on the astrolabe.

name: Habash al-Hasib
summary: Habash al-Hasib al-Marwazi was a Persian astronomer and mathematician who introduced trigonometric functions including tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant. Working at the Abbasid court in Baghdad, he compiled astronomical tables and conducted observations used for calendar reform. His trigonometric innovations were foundational for Islamic and later European mathematics.

name: Sharafeddin Tusi
summary: Sharafeddin Tusi was a Persian mathematician who made significant advances in the study of cubic equations, developing methods for finding their solutions and determining the conditions for the existence of positive roots. His work anticipated concepts in differential calculus and was influential in the development of algebraic geometry.

name: James Clerk Maxwell
summary: James Clerk Maxwell was a Scottish physicist who formulated the classical theory of electromagnetic radiation, unifying electricity, magnetism, and light as manifestations of the same phenomenon. His Maxwell's equations are one of the greatest achievements in physics, predicting electromagnetic waves and leading to radio, television, and modern telecommunications.
timeline: Published 'A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic Field'
Became first Cavendish Professor at Cambridge
Published 'A Treatise on Electricity and Magnetism'
